directives.name: proxy_buffer
directives.doc:
Sets the size of the buffer used for proxying.
By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page.
Depending on a platform, it is either 4K or 8K.

directives.name: proxy_pass_error_message
directives.doc:
Indicates whether to pass the error message obtained during
the authentication on the backend to the client.

directives.name: proxy_protocol
directives.doc:
Enables the
PROXY
protocol for connections to a backend.

directives.name: proxy_smtp_auth
directives.doc:
Enables or disables user authentication on the SMTP backend
using the AUTH command.

directives.name: proxy_timeout
directives.doc:
Sets the timeout between two successive
read or write operations on client or proxied server connections.
If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

directives.name: xclient
directives.doc:
Enables or disables the passing of the
XCLIENT
command with client parameters when connecting to the SMTP backend.

directives.name: set_real_ip_from
directives.doc:
Defines trusted addresses that are known to send correct
replacement addresses.
If the special value unix: is specified,
all UNIX-domain sockets will be trusted.

directives.name: ssl
directives.doc:
This directive was made obsolete in version 1.15.0.
The ssl parameter
of the listen directive
should be used instead.

directives.name: ssl_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format
for the given server.
If intermediate certificates should be specified in addition to a primary
certificate, they should be specified in the same file in the following
order: the primary certificate comes first, then the intermediate certificates.
A secret key in the PEM format may be placed in the same file.

directives.name: ssl_certificate_key
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format
for the given server.

directives.name: ssl_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies the enabled ciphers.
The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the
OpenSSL library, for example:

directives.name: ssl_client_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_conf_command
directives.doc:
Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration
commands.
directives.example:
ssl_conf_command Options PrioritizeChaCha;
ssl_conf_command Ciphersuites TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256;

directives.name: ssl_crl
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL)
in the PEM format used to verify
client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_dhparam
directives.doc: Specifies a file with DH parameters for DHE ciphers.

directives.name: ssl_ecdh_curve
directives.doc: Specifies a curve for ECDHE ciphers.

directives.name: ssl_password_file
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with passphrases for
secret keys
where each passphrase is specified on a separate line.
Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

directives.name: ssl_prefer_server_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies that server ciphers should be preferred over client ciphers
when the SSLv3 and TLS protocols are used.

directives.name: ssl_protocols
directives.doc: Enables the specified protocols.

directives.name: ssl_session_cache
directives.doc:
Sets the types and sizes of caches that store session parameters.
A cache can be of any of the following types:

directives.name: ssl_session_ticket_key
directives.doc:
Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt
and decrypt TLS session tickets.
The directive is necessary if the same key has to be shared between
multiple servers.
By default, a randomly generated key is used.

directives.name: ssl_session_tickets
directives.doc:
Enables or disables session resumption through
TLS session tickets.

directives.name: ssl_session_timeout
directives.doc:
Specifies a time during which a client may reuse the
session parameters.

directives.name: ssl_trusted_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_verify_client
directives.doc:
Enables verification of client certificates.
The verification result is passed in the
“Auth-SSL-Verify” header of the
authentication
request.

directives.name: ssl_verify_depth
directives.doc: Sets the verification depth in the client certificates chain.

directives.name: starttls
imap_auth
directives.doc:
Sets permitted methods of authentication for IMAP clients.
Supported methods are:

directives.name: imap_capabilities
directives.doc:
Sets the
IMAP protocol
extensions list that is passed to the client in response to
the CAPABILITY command.
The authentication methods specified in the imap_auth directive and
STARTTLS
are automatically added to this list depending on the
starttls directive value.

directives.name: imap_client_buffer
directives.doc:
Sets the size of the buffer used for reading IMAP commands.
By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page.
This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

directives.name: pop3_auth
directives.doc:
Sets permitted methods of authentication for POP3 clients.
Supported methods are:

directives.name: pop3_capabilities
directives.doc:
Sets the
POP3 protocol
extensions list that is passed to the client in response to
the CAPA command.
The authentication methods specified in the pop3_auth directive
(SASL extension) and
STLS
are automatically added to this list depending on the
starttls directive value.

directives.name: smtp_auth
directives.doc:
Sets permitted methods of
SASL authentication
for SMTP clients.
Supported methods are:

directives.name: smtp_capabilities
directives.doc:
Sets the SMTP protocol extensions list
that is passed to the client in response to the
EHLO command.
The authentication methods specified in the smtp_auth directive and
STARTTLS
are automatically added to this list depending on the
starttls directive value.

directives.name: smtp_client_buffer
directives.doc:
Sets the size of the buffer used for reading SMTP commands.
By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page.
This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

directives.name: smtp_greeting_delay
directives.doc:
Allows setting a delay before sending an SMTP greeting
in order to reject clients who fail to wait for the greeting before
sending SMTP commands.

directives.name: listen
directives.doc:
Sets the address and port for the socket
on which the server will accept connections.
It is possible to specify just the port.
The address can also be a hostname, for example:

directives.name: preread_buffer_size
directives.doc:
Specifies a size of the
preread buffer.

directives.name: preread_timeout
directives.doc:
Specifies a timeout of the
preread phase.

directives.name: proxy_protocol_timeout
directives.doc:
Specifies a timeout for
reading the PROXY protocol header to complete.
If no entire header is transmitted within this time,
the connection is closed.

directives.name: resolver
directives.doc:
Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers
into addresses, for example:

directives.name: resolver_timeout
directives.doc: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

directives.name: server
directives.doc: Sets the configuration for a server.

directives.name: stream
directives.doc:
Provides the configuration file context in which the stream server directives
are specified.

directives.name: tcp_nodelay
directives.doc:
Enables or disables the use of the TCP_NODELAY option.
The option is enabled for both client and proxied server connections.

directives.name: variables_hash_bucket_size
directives.doc:
Sets the bucket size for the variables hash table.
The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate
document.

directives.name: variables_hash_max_size
directives.doc:
Sets the maximum size of the variables hash table.
The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate
document.

directives.name: allow
directives.doc:
Allows access for the specified network or address.
If the special value unix: is specified,
allows access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

directives.name: deny
directives.doc:
Denies access for the specified network or address.
If the special value unix: is specified,
denies access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

directives.name: geo
directives.doc:
Describes the dependency of values of the specified variable
on the client IP address.
By default, the address is taken from the $remote_addr variable,
but it can also be taken from another variable, for example:

directives.name: geoip_country
directives.doc:
Specifies a database used to determine the country
depending on the client IP address.
The following variables are available when using this database:

directives.name: geoip_city
directives.doc:
Specifies a database used to determine the country, region, and city
depending on the client IP address.
The following variables are available when using this database:

directives.name: geoip_org
directives.doc:
Specifies a database used to determine the organization
depending on the client IP address.
The following variable is available when using this database:

directives.name: js_access
directives.doc:
Sets an njs function which will be called at the
access phase.
Since 0.4.0,
a module function can be referenced.

directives.name: js_fetch_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies the enabled ciphers for HTTPS connections
with Fetch API.
The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

directives.name: js_fetch_protocols
directives.doc:
Enables the specified protocols for HTTPS connections
with Fetch API.

directives.name: js_fetch_trusted_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to
verify
the HTTPS certificate
with Fetch API.

directives.name: js_fetch_verify_depth
directives.doc:
Sets the verification depth in the HTTPS server certificates chain
with Fetch API.

directives.name: js_filter
directives.doc:
Sets a data filter.
Since 0.4.0,
a module function can be referenced.

directives.name: js_import
directives.doc:
Imports a module that implements location and variable handlers in njs.
The export_name is used as a namespace
to access module functions.
If the export_name is not specified,
the module name will be used as a namespace.

directives.name: js_include
directives.doc: Specifies a file that implements server and variable handlers in njs:

directives.name: js_path
directives.doc: Sets an additional path for njs modules.

directives.name: js_preread
directives.doc:
Sets an njs function which will be called at the
preread phase.
Since 0.4.0,
a module function can be referenced.

directives.name: js_set
directives.doc:
Sets an njs function
for the specified variable.
Since 0.4.0,
a module function can be referenced.

directives.name: js_var
directives.doc:
Declares
a writable
variable.
The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

directives.name: keyval
directives.doc:
Creates a new $variable whose value
is looked up by the key in the key-value database.
Matching rules are defined by the
type parameter of the
keyval_zone directive.
The database is stored in a shared memory zone
specified by the zone parameter.

directives.name: keyval_zone
directives.doc:
Sets the name and size of the shared memory zone
that keeps the key-value database.
Key-value pairs are managed by the
API.
directives.example:
keyval_zone zone=one:32k state=/var/lib/nginx/state/one.keyval; # path for Linux
keyval_zone zone=one:32k state=/var/db/nginx/state/one.keyval;  # path for FreeBSD

directives.name: limit_conn
directives.doc:
Sets the shared memory zone
and the maximum allowed number of connections for a given key value.
When this limit is exceeded, the server will close the connection.
For example, the directives

directives.name: limit_conn_dry_run
directives.doc:
Enables the dry run mode.
In this mode, the number of connections is not limited, however,
in the shared memory zone, the number of excessive connections is accounted
as usual.

directives.name: limit_conn_log_level
directives.doc:
Sets the desired logging level for cases when the server
limits the number of connections.

directives.name: limit_conn_zone
directives.doc:
Sets parameters for a shared memory zone
that will keep states for various keys.
In particular, the state includes the current number of connections.
The key can contain text, variables,
and their combinations (1.11.2).
Connections with an empty key value are not accounted.
Usage example:

directives.name: access_log
directives.doc:
Sets the path, format,
and configuration for a buffered log write.
Several logs can be specified on the same configuration level.
Logging to syslog
can be configured by specifying
the “syslog:” prefix in the first parameter.
The special value off cancels all
access_log directives on the current level.

directives.name: log_format
directives.doc: Specifies the log format, for example:

directives.name: open_log_file_cache
directives.doc:
Defines a cache that stores the file descriptors of frequently used logs
whose names contain variables.
The directive has the following parameters:

directives.name: map
directives.doc:
Creates a new variable whose value
depends on values of one or more of the source variables
specified in the first parameter.

directives.name: map_hash_bucket_size
directives.doc:
Sets the bucket size for the map variables hash tables.
Default value depends on the processor’s cache line size.
The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate
document.

directives.name: map_hash_max_size
directives.doc:
Sets the maximum size of the map variables
hash tables.
The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate
document.

directives.name: proxy_bind
directives.doc:
Makes outgoing connections to a proxied server originate
from the specified local IP address.
Parameter value can contain variables (1.11.2).
The special value off cancels the effect
of the proxy_bind directive
inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the
system to auto-assign the local IP address.

directives.name: proxy_buffer_size
directives.doc:
Sets the size of the buffer used for reading data
from the proxied server.
Also sets the size of the buffer used for reading data
from the client.

directives.name: proxy_connect_timeout
directives.doc: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_download_rate
directives.doc:
Limits the speed of reading the data from the proxied server.
The rate is specified in bytes per second.
The zero value disables rate limiting.
The limit is set per a connection, so if nginx simultaneously opens
two connections to the proxied server,
the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

directives.name: proxy_half_close
directives.doc:
Enables or disables closing
each direction of a TCP connection independently (“TCP half-close”).
If enabled, proxying over TCP will be kept
until both sides close the connection.

directives.name: proxy_next_upstream
directives.doc:
When a connection to the proxied server cannot be established, determines
whether a client connection will be passed to the next server.

directives.name: proxy_next_upstream_timeout
directives.doc:
Limits the time allowed to pass a connection to the
next server.
The 0 value turns off this limitation.

directives.name: proxy_next_upstream_tries
directives.doc:
Limits the number of possible tries for passing a connection to the
next server.
The 0 value turns off this limitation.

directives.name: proxy_pass
directives.doc:
Sets the address of a proxied server.
The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address,
and a port:

directives.name: proxy_protocol
directives.doc:
Enables the
PROXY
protocol for connections to a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_requests
directives.doc:
Sets the number of client datagrams at which
binding between a client and existing UDP stream session is dropped.
After receiving the specified number of datagrams, next datagram
from the same client starts a new session.
The session terminates when all client datagrams are transmitted
to a proxied server and the expected number of
responses is received,
or when it reaches a timeout.

directives.name: proxy_responses
directives.doc:
Sets the number of datagrams expected from the proxied server
in response to a client datagram
if the UDP
protocol is used.
The number serves as a hint for session termination.
By default, the number of datagrams is not limited.

directives.name: proxy_session_drop
directives.doc:
Enables terminating all sessions to a proxied server
after it was removed from the group or marked as permanently unavailable.
This can occur because of
re-resolve
or with the API
DELETE
command.
A server can be marked as permanently unavailable if it is considered
unhealthy
or with the API
PATCH
command.
Each session is terminated when the next
read or write event is processed for the client or proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_socket_keepalive
directives.doc:
Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior
for outgoing connections to a proxied server.
By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket.
If the directive is set to the value “on”, the
SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

directives.name: proxy_ssl
directives.doc: Enables the SSL/TLS protocol for connections to a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format
used for authentication to a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_certificate_key
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format
used for authentication to a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies the enabled ciphers for connections to a proxied server.
The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_conf_command
directives.doc:
Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration
commands
when establishing a connection with the proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_crl
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL)
in the PEM format used to verify
the certificate of the proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_name
directives.doc:
Allows overriding the server name used to
verify
the certificate of the proxied server and to be
passed through SNI
when establishing a connection with the proxied server.
The server name can also be specified using variables (1.11.3).

directives.name: proxy_ssl_password_file
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with passphrases for
secret keys
where each passphrase is specified on a separate line.
Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_protocols
directives.doc: Enables the specified protocols for connections to a proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_server_name
directives.doc:
Enables or disables passing of the server name through
TLS
Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066)
when establishing a connection with the proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_session_reuse
directives.doc:
Determines whether SSL sessions can be reused when working with
the proxied server.
If the errors
“SSL3_GET_FINISHED:digest check failed”
appear in the logs, try disabling session reuse.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_trusted_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify
the certificate of the proxied server.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_verify
directives.doc: Enables or disables verification of the proxied server certificate.

directives.name: proxy_ssl_verify_depth
directives.doc: Sets the verification depth in the proxied server certificates chain.

directives.name: proxy_timeout
directives.doc:
Sets the timeout between two successive
read or write operations on client or proxied server connections.
If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

directives.name: proxy_upload_rate
directives.doc:
Limits the speed of reading the data from the client.
The rate is specified in bytes per second.
The zero value disables rate limiting.
The limit is set per a connection, so if the client simultaneously opens
two connections,
the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

directives.name: set_real_ip_from
directives.doc:
Defines trusted addresses that are known to send correct
replacement addresses.
If the special value unix: is specified,
all UNIX-domain sockets will be trusted.

directives.name: return
directives.doc:
Specifies a value to send to the client.
The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

directives.name: set
directives.doc:
Sets a value for the specified variable.
The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

directives.name: split_clients
directives.doc: Creates a variable for A/B testing, for example:

directives.name: ssl_alpn
directives.doc:
Specifies the list of supported
ALPN protocols.
One of the protocols must be
negotiated if the client uses ALPN:

directives.name: ssl_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format
for the given server.
If intermediate certificates should be specified in addition to a primary
certificate, they should be specified in the same file in the following
order: the primary certificate comes first, then the intermediate certificates.
A secret key in the PEM format may be placed in the same file.

directives.name: ssl_certificate_key
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format
for the given server.

directives.name: ssl_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies the enabled ciphers.
The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the
OpenSSL library, for example:

directives.name: ssl_client_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_conf_command
directives.doc:
Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration
commands.
directives.example:
ssl_conf_command Options PrioritizeChaCha;
ssl_conf_command Ciphersuites TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256;

directives.name: ssl_crl
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL)
in the PEM format used to verify
client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_dhparam
directives.doc: Specifies a file with DH parameters for DHE ciphers.

directives.name: ssl_ecdh_curve
directives.doc: Specifies a curve for ECDHE ciphers.

directives.name: ssl_handshake_timeout
directives.doc: Specifies a timeout for the SSL handshake to complete.

directives.name: ssl_password_file
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with passphrases for
secret keys
where each passphrase is specified on a separate line.
Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

directives.name: ssl_prefer_server_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies that server ciphers should be preferred over client ciphers
when the SSLv3 and TLS protocols are used.

directives.name: ssl_protocols
directives.doc: Enables the specified protocols.

directives.name: ssl_session_cache
directives.doc:
Sets the types and sizes of caches that store session parameters.
A cache can be of any of the following types:

directives.name: ssl_session_ticket_key
directives.doc:
Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt
and decrypt TLS session tickets.
The directive is necessary if the same key has to be shared between
multiple servers.
By default, a randomly generated key is used.

directives.name: ssl_session_tickets
directives.doc:
Enables or disables session resumption through
TLS session tickets.

directives.name: ssl_session_timeout
directives.doc:
Specifies a time during which a client may reuse the
session parameters.

directives.name: ssl_trusted_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify client certificates.

directives.name: ssl_verify_client
directives.doc:
Enables verification of client certificates.
The verification result is stored in the
$ssl_client_verify variable.
If an error has occurred during the client certificate verification
or a client has not presented the required certificate,
the connection is closed.

directives.name: ssl_verify_depth
directives.doc: Sets the verification depth in the client certificates chain.

directives.name: ssl_preread
directives.doc:
Enables extracting information from the ClientHello message at
the preread phase.

directives.name: upstream
directives.doc:
Defines a group of servers.
Servers can listen on different ports.
In addition, servers listening on TCP and UNIX-domain sockets
can be mixed.

directives.name: server
directives.doc:
Defines the address and other parameters
of a server.
The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address
with an obligatory port, or as a UNIX-domain socket path
specified after the “unix:” prefix.
A domain name that resolves to several IP addresses defines
multiple servers at once.

directives.name: zone
directives.doc:
Defines the name and size of the shared
memory zone that keeps the group’s configuration and run-time state that are
shared between worker processes.
Several groups may share the same zone.
In this case, it is enough to specify the size only once.

directives.name: state
directives.doc:
Specifies a file that keeps the state
of the dynamically configurable group.
directives.example:
state /var/lib/nginx/state/servers.conf; # path for Linux
state /var/db/nginx/state/servers.conf;  # path for FreeBSD

directives.name: hash
directives.doc:
Specifies a load balancing method for a server group
where the client-server mapping is based on the hashed key value.
The key can contain text, variables,
and their combinations (1.11.2).
Usage example:

directives.name: least_conn
directives.doc:
Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection
is passed to the server with the least number of active connections,
taking into account weights of servers.
If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a
weighted round-robin balancing method.

directives.name: least_time
directives.doc:
Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection
is passed to the server with the least average time and
least number of active connections, taking into account weights of servers.
If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a
weighted round-robin balancing method.

directives.name: random
directives.doc:
Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection
is passed to a randomly selected server, taking into account weights
of servers.

directives.name: resolver
directives.doc:
Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers
into addresses, for example:

directives.name: resolver_timeout
directives.doc: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

directives.name: health_check
directives.doc:
Enables periodic health checks of the servers in a
group.

directives.name: health_check_timeout
directives.doc:
Overrides the
proxy_timeout
value for health checks.

directives.name: match
directives.doc: Defines the named test set used to verify server responses to health checks.

directives.name: zone_sync
directives.doc:
Enables the synchronization of shared memory zones between cluster nodes.
Cluster nodes are defined using zone_sync_server directives.

directives.name: zone_sync_buffers
directives.doc:
Sets the number and size of the
per-zone buffers used for pushing zone contents.
By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page.
This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

directives.name: zone_sync_connect_retry_interval
directives.doc: Defines an interval between connection attempts to another cluster node.

directives.name: zone_sync_connect_timeout
directives.doc: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with another cluster node.

directives.name: zone_sync_interval
directives.doc: Defines an interval for polling updates in a shared memory zone.

directives.name: zone_sync_recv_buffer_size
directives.doc:
Sets size of a per-connection receive buffer used to parse
incoming stream of synchronization messages.
The buffer size must be equal or greater than one of the
zone_sync_buffers.
By default, the buffer size is equal to
zone_sync_buffers size
multiplied by number.

directives.name: zone_sync_server
directives.doc:
Defines the address of a cluster node.
The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address
with a mandatory port, or as a UNIX-domain socket path
specified after the “unix:” prefix.
A domain name that resolves to several IP addresses defines
multiple nodes at once.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl
directives.doc: Enables the SSL/TLS protocol for connections to another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format
used for authentication to another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_certificate_key
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format
used for authentication to another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_ciphers
directives.doc:
Specifies the enabled ciphers for connections to another cluster server.
The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_conf_command
directives.doc:
Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration
commands
when establishing a connection with another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_crl
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL)
in the PEM format used to verify
the certificate of another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_name
directives.doc:
Allows overriding the server name used to
verify
the certificate of a cluster server and to be
passed through SNI
when establishing a connection with the cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_password_file
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with passphrases for
secret keys
where each passphrase is specified on a separate line.
Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_protocols
directives.doc: Enables the specified protocols for connections to another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_server_name
directives.doc:
Enables or disables passing of the server name through
TLS
Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066)
when establishing a connection with another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_trusted_certificate
directives.doc:
Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format
used to verify
the certificate of another cluster server.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_verify
directives.doc: Enables or disables verification of another cluster server certificate.

directives.name: zone_sync_ssl_verify_depth
directives.doc: Sets the verification depth in another cluster server certificates chain.

directives.name: zone_sync_timeout
directives.doc:
Sets the timeout between two successive
read or write operations on connection to another cluster node.
If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

directives.name: google_perftools_profiles
directives.doc:
Sets a file name that keeps profiling information of
nginx worker process.
The ID of the worker process is always a part of the file name
and is appended to the end of the file name, after a dot.

variables.name: $arg_
variables.doc: argument name in the request line

variables.name: $args
variables.doc: arguments in the request line

variables.name: $binary_remote_addr
variables.doc:
client address in a binary form, value’s length is always 4 bytes
for IPv4 addresses or 16 bytes for IPv6 addresses

variables.name: $body_bytes_sent
variables.doc:
number of bytes sent to a client, not counting the response header;
this variable is compatible with the “%B” parameter of the
mod_log_config
Apache module

variables.name: $bytes_sent
variables.doc: number of bytes sent to a client (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

variables.name: $connection
variables.doc: connection serial number (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

variables.name: $connection_requests
variables.doc: current number of requests made through a connection (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

variables.name: $connection_time
variables.doc: connection time in seconds with a milliseconds resolution (1.19.10)

variables.name: $content_length
variables.doc: “Content-Length” request header field

variables.name: $content_type
variables.doc: “Content-Type” request header field

variables.name: $cookie_
variables.doc: the name cookie

variables.name: $document_root
variables.doc:
root or alias directive’s value
for the current request

variables.name: $document_uri
variables.doc: same as $uri

variables.name: $host
variables.doc:
in this order of precedence:
host name from the request line, or
host name from the “Host” request header field, or
the server name matching a request

variables.name: $hostname
variables.doc: host name

variables.name: $http_
$https
$is_args
variables.doc:
“?” if a request line has arguments,
or an empty string otherwise

variables.name: $limit_rate
variables.doc:
setting this variable enables response rate limiting;
see limit_rate

variables.name: $msec
variables.doc: current time in seconds with the milliseconds resolution (1.3.9, 1.2.6)

variables.name: $nginx_version
variables.doc: nginx version

variables.name: $pid
variables.doc: PID of the worker process

variables.name: $pipe
variables.doc:
“p” if request was pipelined, “.”
otherwise (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_addr
variables.doc:
client address from the PROXY protocol header (1.5.12)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_port
variables.doc:
client port from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.0)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_server_addr
variables.doc:
server address from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_server_port
variables.doc:
server port from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $query_string
variables.doc: same as $args

variables.name: $realpath_root
variables.doc:
an absolute pathname corresponding to the
root or alias directive’s value
for the current request,
with all symbolic links resolved to real paths

variables.name: $remote_addr
variables.doc: client address

variables.name: $remote_port
variables.doc: client port

variables.name: $remote_user
variables.doc: user name supplied with the Basic authentication

variables.name: $request
variables.doc: full original request line

variables.name: $request_body
variables.doc:
request body

The variable’s value is made available in locations
processed by the
proxy_pass,
fastcgi_pass,
uwsgi_pass,
and
scgi_pass
directives when the request body was read to
a memory buffer.

variables.name: $request_body_file
variables.doc:
name of a temporary file with the request body

At the end of processing, the file needs to be removed.
To always write the request body to a file,
client_body_in_file_only needs to be enabled.
When the name of a temporary file is passed in a proxied request
or in a request to a FastCGI/uwsgi/SCGI server,
passing the request body should be disabled by the

proxy_pass_request_body off,

fastcgi_pass_request_body off,

uwsgi_pass_request_body off, or

scgi_pass_request_body off
directives, respectively.

variables.name: $request_completion
variables.doc:
“OK” if a request has completed,
or an empty string otherwise

variables.name: $request_filename
variables.doc:
file path for the current request, based on the
root or alias
directives, and the request URI

variables.name: $request_id
variables.doc:
unique request identifier
generated from 16 random bytes, in hexadecimal (1.11.0)

variables.name: $request_length
variables.doc:
request length (including request line, header, and request body)
(1.3.12, 1.2.7)

variables.name: $request_method
variables.doc:
request method, usually
“GET” or “POST”

variables.name: $request_time
$request_uri
variables.doc: full original request URI (with arguments)

variables.name: $scheme
variables.doc: request scheme, “http” or “https”

variables.name: $sent_http_
$sent_trailer_
$server_addr
variables.doc:
an address of the server which accepted a request

Computing a value of this variable usually requires one system call.
To avoid a system call, the listen directives
must specify addresses and use the bind parameter.

variables.name: $server_name
variables.doc: name of the server which accepted a request

variables.name: $server_port
variables.doc: port of the server which accepted a request

variables.name: $server_protocol
variables.doc:
request protocol, usually
“HTTP/1.0”,
“HTTP/1.1”,
or
“HTTP/2.0”

variables.name: $status
variables.doc: response status (1.3.2, 1.2.2)

variables.name: $tcpinfo_
variables.doc:
information about the client TCP connection; available on systems
that support the TCP_INFO socket option

variables.name: $time_iso8601
variables.doc: local time in the ISO 8601 standard format (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

variables.name: $time_local
variables.doc: local time in the Common Log Format (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

variables.name: $uri
variables.doc:
current URI in request, normalized

The value of $uri may change during request processing,
e.g. when doing internal redirects, or when using index files.

variables.name: $binary_remote_addr
variables.doc:
client address in a binary form, value’s length is always 4 bytes
for IPv4 addresses or 16 bytes for IPv6 addresses

variables.name: $bytes_received
variables.doc: number of bytes received from a client (1.11.4)

variables.name: $bytes_sent
variables.doc: number of bytes sent to a client

variables.name: $connection
variables.doc: connection serial number

variables.name: $hostname
variables.doc: host name

variables.name: $msec
variables.doc: current time in seconds with the milliseconds resolution

variables.name: $nginx_version
variables.doc: nginx version

variables.name: $pid
variables.doc: PID of the worker process

variables.name: $protocol
variables.doc:
protocol used to communicate with the client:
TCP or UDP (1.11.4)

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_addr
variables.doc:
client address from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.4)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_port
variables.doc:
client port from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.4)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_server_addr
variables.doc:
server address from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $proxy_protocol_server_port
variables.doc:
server port from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)

The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the
proxy_protocol parameter
in the listen directive.

variables.name: $remote_addr
variables.doc: client address

variables.name: $remote_port
variables.doc: client port

variables.name: $server_addr
variables.doc:
an address of the server which accepted a connection

Computing a value of this variable usually requires one system call.
To avoid a system call, the listen directives
must specify addresses and use the bind parameter.

variables.name: $server_port
variables.doc: port of the server which accepted a connection

variables.name: $session_time
variables.doc:
session duration in seconds with a milliseconds resolution
(1.11.4);

variables.name: $status
variables.doc:
session status (1.11.4), can be one of the following:


200

session completed successfully


400

client data could not be parsed, for example,
the PROXY protocol header


403

access forbidden, for example, when access is limited for
certain client addresses


500

internal server error


502

bad gateway, for example,
if an upstream server could not be selected or reached.


503

service unavailable, for example, when access is limited by the
number of connections

variables.name: $time_iso8601
variables.doc: local time in the ISO 8601 standard format

variables.name: $time_local
variables.doc: local time in the Common Log Format
